 THAILAND UNIVERSITIES SCIENCE AND ENGINEERING EDUCATION PROJECT I. SCIENCE AND ENGINEERING EDUCATION A. Introduction 1.1 Sound macroeconomic policies have underpinned Thailand's economic performance in recent years, making it among the best in the world with real GDP growing at almost 11% p.a. during 1987-1993. Rapid industrialization has been a key to this performance. Manufacturing now accounts for over 27% of GDP giving Thailand the largest manufacturing sector within ASEAN. A strong export performance has been sustained with manufacturing exports growing about 25% p.a. in real terms during 1986-93. This success has been built largely on the expansion of relatively low-technology, low wage/skill production in such industries as textiles, apparel and basic electronics and sustained by a steady flow of foreign direct investment. However, Thailand's comparative advantage in these industries is being eroded and to sustain growth prospects in the long term, the country will need to maintain its competitiveness and move up the technology chain to produce higher value-added technology- intensive products. 1.2 In order to do this, Thailand must address an increasingly serious human resource constraint in the form of rising shortages of scientific and technical skills accompanied by a relatively low level of education in the workforce. While this broad-based human resource problem must be addressed, the key leadership role in Thailand's technological transformation will be played by graduates in science and engineering produced by the universities. Shortages of scientists and engineers have been widely reported and international indicators show that Thailand is not well-endowed with scientific and technical (S&T) skills. S&T manpower is currently around 13 per 10,000 of the labor force compared with Korea which had 37 per 10,000 in 1990. The annual number of engineering graduates per million of population is currently around 70 in Thailand compared with nearly 660 per million in Korea in 1991. A low level of R&D investment and little private sector contribution is another area in which Thailand is lagging. Policies are being implemented to raise the output of scientists and engineers as well as to strengthen R&D activities (paras. 1.34-1.36). B. Overview of Higher Education 1.3 Thailand's education system is highly developed. A strong commitment to equity has led to universal access to primary education, with high completion rates, as well as to the establishment of effective nonformal programs to increase adult literacy. Lower secondary education has been expanded to provide places for about half of the primary school graduates, and in principle there is an upper secondary place for each graduate of lower secondary
 2 education, nearly half of whom are in vocational schools and colleges. The secondary enrollment rate in Thailand stagnated through the 1980s at about 30% of the age group, which was about half the rates in Malaysia and Indonesia and one-third of those in Korea and Taiwan, China. The Government responded to the problem by extending the basic education cycle from 6 to 9 years i.e. to include the first three years of secondary education. By 1997, it is planned that all grade 6 graduates will enter grade 7. This policy will result in a corresponding expansion of upper secondary enrollments. At the end of secondary schooling, about 43% of the grade 12 students take the National University Entrance Examination, a vehicle to screen entrants to degree programs in conventional public universities in which enrollments have remained tightly controlled. The number of places for new entrants is set at 42,502 or 32% of the total number of candidates (134,654). 1.4 The Thai higher education system is unique in its composition, encompassing conventional public and private institutions, as well as two large-scale open/distance universities, all of which enrolled about 733,343 students in 1994 (Annex 1). Traditional public institutions admit students strictly on academic criteria, and are characterized by relatively small enrollments (155,602 in 1993) which have been quite stable in recent years, and high unit costs (B53,040 or $2,210 per student), of which only about 5-10% is recovered via student fees. The open/distance universities, Ramkhamhaeng University (RU) and Sukhothai Thammathirat Open University (STOU), enroll the largest number of students, about 494,115 in 1993. Their unit costs are low (B600 per student),' about half of which are recovered via student fees. With an enrollment ratio of 20%,2 the coverage of the Thai higher education system is well above that in other countries at the same per capita income level. 1.5 There are 35 private colleges and universities, consisting of 70% for profit and 30% non-profit. Most of the operating costs are financed through student fees. Almost half of these institutions are located in the Bangkok metropolitan region while the remainder are scattered throughout the country. They offer mainly bachelor's degree programs, but graduate programs are gradually being introduced. Private universities are also starting to enter engineering education (para. 1.36). In recent years, enrollments in private colleges and universities have been growing more rapidly than that in public institutions, from 117,390 students in 1992 to 141,920 in 1994. l World Bank (1991) "Decision and Change in Thailand: Three Studies in Support of the Seventh Plan". 2 Total enrollment in higher education divided by the population in the relevant age group. However, the coverage rate needs to be adjusted to assess the volume of graduates produced. In the case of Thailand, the adjustment is necessary since a sizable share of the students in the large-scale open/distance system, mainly in STOU, are employed people not seeking a degree but simply to upgrade their skills. Moreover, a significant number of students in both RU and STOU attend part-time, and so complete their courses over a much longer period (4-8 years) than their peers in the conventional institutions. This pattern suggests that the number of "active" students is much less than enrollment. An estimate of "active" students can be derived by applying the 25% graduation rate to the total enrolled. Adding this result to enrollments in the traditional closed universities and MOE's degree granting institutions gives an adjusted total higher education enrollment in 1987 of about 423,000 which translates to an enrollment ratio of 11.9%. This is still above the average of around 10% for a country at Thailand's income level.
 3 1.6 The Ministry of University Affairs (MUA) oversees the 23 public and 35 private conventional universities and colleges, as well as the two open universities. In addition, the Ministry of Education (MOE) has authority over 36 teacher colleges (which also offer a range of non-teaching vocational courses) and 31 campuses of the Rajamangala Institute of Technology (RIT) which offer degree level courses as well as certificate and diploma courses. Enrollments in these two systems were about 270,000 and 72,100 respectively in 1994. Science and Engineering Education 1.7 There are 23 faculties of science in the public universities, including Ramkhamhaeng Open University (Annex 2). New faculties of engineering and science are being established in three other public universities. Plans are being made for the establishment of four new public universities with strong faculties of science and engineering. The existing science faculties can be categorized as: (a) faculties developing new undergraduate science degrees (either as a new university, as a new faculty of science or as converting a science support program into a full science degree program); or as (b) faculties with established degree programs which are trying to upgrade the quality of their activities in a time of enrollment expansion. Within the faculties there are 112 departments concentrated mainly in mathematics and related subjects (29% of total departments), biological sciences (21%), chemistry (19%) and physical sciences (15%). 1.8 Admission to the faculties of science and engineering is based on the candidate possessing a secondary school certificate with the science/math elective and on his/her ranking, within the grade range set by each university, obtained by the candidate in the National University Entrance Examination. These requirements are applicable to all admissions to the public universities in the Bangkok metropolitan region. In the regional universities, 50% of admissions is allocated to those who have passed the Entrance Examination and have chosen the regional university and faculty. The remaining 50% is allocated each year to secondary school certificate holders in the region who pass the regional university's own entrance examination. If quotas need to be made up, there is provision for some individual departments to set their own entrance examinations. This approach has improved the equity of access to universities outside Bangkok and given rural students greater opportunities to study science and engineering and thereby qualify for high-paying employment in the future. 1.9 Enrollments in the science faculties in the public universities (excluding RU, which experienced substantial annual fluctuations) increased at about 11.5% p.a. during 1989-93. Enrollments in the engineering faculties grew at about 14.5% during the same period giving a combined annual enrollment growth of around 13%. This is not appreciably below the target of 15% annual enrollment growth in science and engineering called for in the Seventh Plan (1992- 96), (para. 1.35). The annual output of bachelors of science was 2,240 (including 598 from an open university) in 1990 and this had increased to 3,030 in 1993.
 4 1.10 The faculties of science offer programs in two categories: (a) courses for students majoring in science i.e. those pursuing a B.S. degree; and (b) service courses for non-major students who are enrolled in other faculties such as engineering, medicine and agriculture. The number of credit hours required for the award of a B.S. degree is in the range 130-150 with some variation between universities. Typically, basic science courses account for nearly 30% of total credit hours and major subjects for nearly 50%. General education, including languages, accounts for the remainder. Within the science major, laboratory work takes up 15-25% of the total, becoming more important in the senior years of the B.S. degree. 1.11 There are 15 schools of engineering in the public universities (Annex 2) offering the B.Eng. degree in 23 disciplines. The structure of enrollments tends to reflect a past lack of emphasis on the production of S&T manpower. Enrollments in undergraduate basic science and engineering programs (35,750 in the public conventional universities) represent only about 23% of total enrollments. In Korea, the proportion is 36%. Females represent 10% of total engineering enrollments but the figure rises to 52% in science, concentrated mainly in biology and related disciplines. Market information does influence engineering enrollments. This is reflected in a declining trend in enrollments in mining while there is a substantial increase in computer/electrical/electronic engineering, as a consequence of the growing demand to service the computer/electronics/information technology diffusion. Increasing enrollments are also evident in environmental engineering, as environmental legislation begins to impact on infrastructure services and in industrial engineering, as industrial productivity gains capture the attention of industrial managers. 1.12 Two models of undergraduate engineering education coexist, differing in the extent of specialization and the practical orientation of the subject matter. In the first group are most engineering departments which place emphasis on the fundamentals of engineering synthesis in a given engineering discipline, with offerings of departmental majors and technical electives that contribute to the flexibility of the programs. The gap in hard core engineering education (e.g. in production engineering, design) is shared with industry during the compulsory industrial training requirement (para. 1.13). Examples are electrical engineering departments with majors in electrical power; electronics and communications; and control systems. Another is the civil engineering department with departmental majors in structural, geo-technical, transportation, construction and environmental engineering. The second group comprises specialized engineering departments with emphasis on in-house hard core engineering and work on technical applications. They offer training with a strong vocational orientation and have close links with industry. Examples of such programs are the departments of instrumentation and control engineering, telecommunications engineering, electronics, and computer engineering. Accreditation practice has a basis similar to that of the US Accreditation Board for Engineering and Technology, where engineering professional societies determine periodically the distribution of semester hours credits among science subjects (Annex 3).
 5 1.13 Most engineering departments have, on the average, a. satisfactory minimum credit requirement of 150 credit units for the undergraduate degree. Each engineering discipline contains a mix of natural sciences, mathematics and engineering sciences. This mix serves to diversify and broaden the spectrum of course offerings within the engineering specialization. The fundamentals of computer engineering and engineering graphics are required subjects for all undergraduate students during the first two years of studies. In addition, a compulsory industrial training of 240 hours is also required at the end of the third year of studies. 1.14 The internal efficiency of science and engineering programs is high. In science the passing rate is around 88%. It should also be recognized that the drop-out/failure rate is less than the 12% implied from the previous figure because a number of students complete successfully the first year of the B.S. program and then transfer to other majors such as engineering and medicine. In engineering, the passing rate is almost identical at 87%. There is a tendency for dropout rates to be higher in the newer regional universities but this reflects in part the transfer of some of students to more prestigious universities after successfully completing first year studies. 1.15 Studies have shown that engineering graduates have no difficulty finding employment.3 The placement rates are: 100% for structural and construction engineering; 90- 98% for materials handling technology, production engineering, mechanical engineering, electrical, and chemical engineering; and 80-88% for civil engineering and petroleum engineering. The employment of science graduates is harder to track because there is a much looser fit between science qualifications and job requirements than in the case of engineers. Data for 1989 show an employment rate of 82% for BS graduates and the current rate is undoubtedly higher due to the increasing demand for science-trained manpower in recent years. Financing 1.16 Public education is supported almost entirely by the central government. The share of the central government budget allocated to education grew from 17% in 1989 to 19.6% in 1993, and over the same period total education expenditure (public and private) increased its share in GDP from about 2.7 to 3.6%. In 1993, public expenditure by level was allocated as follows: 49% primary, 28% secondary, 17% higher and 6% other (including assistance to private schools and educational services and support). 1.17 The share of higher education as a percentage of total education expenditure declined steadily during the last decade. As a percentage of the national budget, higher education represented 4.6% in the late 1960s; this had increased to 5.0% in 1976, but had decreased to 3.4% by 1990. Academic Staffing 1.26 Faculty qualifications need to be raised. Only about 27% of engineering faculty and 31% of the science faculty have doctorates (compared with about 80% of such faculty in Korea). Most of the faculty have masters degrees and many of them are young and are suitable candidates for doctoral studies. The problem is being addressed through the teaching staff development program which is sending qualified academics overseas to obtain higher degrees (para. 1.24). 1.27 The overall staff/student ratio in the engineering faculties is around 1:18, on the basis of the student enrollments in each of the 4 years of undergraduate studies and graduate programs. Curriculum 1.28 Current engineering and science education curricula often do not reflect adequately the emerging needs of the country's technology development. For example, the faculties of engineering offer the B. Eng. in 23 disciplines but lack undergraduate disciplines associated with materials engineering, biotechnology and machinery design engineering. However, efforts are now being made by several universities to offer these and related disciplines. 1.29 While there is some interdisciplinary collaboration between the faculty of engineering and the other faculties in the preparation of final year student projects, and students have the option of free electives, there is no major effort in interdisciplinary studies in areas where it is most needed such as environmental engineering, where the emphasis continues to be on water, sewage and soils to the exclusion of air/atmospheric pollution. 1.30 Although there is a required industrial training period as part of the curriculum, this does not make up for the shortcomings of the programs offered by many faculties of engineering, where laboratory work and practice account for only 8% of the total credit units compared with 20% in Korea." Furthermore, the placement of students for industrial training is expected to become increasingly difficult as enrollments expand. Many testing machines stand idle as spare parts are no longer available in the market. D. Government's Policies and Plans 1.33 The Seventh Plan (1992-96) recognizes that expansion of secondary education must be given a high priority if the education level of the workforce is to be raised to enhance productivity and also to provide the basis for the expansion of higher education. The Plan calls for extending compulsory education from six to nine years. The transition rate from primary to secondary was planned to rise to at least 73% by 1996 and this target has already been exceeded - the rate being 86% in 1994. Consequently, the Government now intends to achieve a transition rate of 100% by 1997. The major impact of the expansion has been felt outside Bangkok where families in the provinces have responded positively to special incentive programs to increase enrollments.12 The Plan also recognizes that a more advanced technological future for Thailand must be underpinned by greater emphasis on education in science, mathematics, foreign languages and in vocational and technical fields. This would be achieved through revising relevant curricula at all levels, upgrading academic staff in higher education through fellowships for higher degrees, strengthening inservice teacher training, and modernizing laboratories and workshops. These quality-improving investments would underpin the policy of increasing the supply of technically and scientifically-trained manpower at all levels, in response to serious shortages in the labor market. 1.34 Within the university subsector, the Plan addresses concerns about shortages of S&T manpower by laying down specific targets for a significant expansion in the production of 12 See Staff Appraisal Report of the Secondary Education Quality Improvement Project.

The Government is therefore implementing a program which provides about 200 overseas fellowships per year for faculty to pursue graduate degrees. This is complemented by a program of practical training overseas to ensure that well-qualified faculty are exposed to the latest trends in science and engineering teaching, relevant research, new teaching technologies, etc. The lack of up-to-date equipment and weak management are widespread in the science and engineering laboratories and this is lowering the quality of courses and inhibiting research. The overall direction of Bank lending under the six projects was consistent with education policy as it evolved under the first five national plans (1962-86). The first two projects focused on increasing the supply of technical manpower for industry and agriculture. Later projects had a broader educational focus and were consistent with the major educational reforms, introduced in 1978, which aimed at equality of educational opportunity, curriculum reform and improved management of the education system. Consequently, the later projects focused on the expansion of educational capacity in the rural areas, the introduction of diversified secondary curricula and the strengthening of education management." 2.2 The first education project in Thailand (Ln. 471-TH) supported quality improvement and expansion of outputs in selected vocational institutions. The PPAR for the project (Report No. 770, June 13, 1975) concluded that the project was implemented successfully. Equipment procurement was delayed initially due to the late arrival of advisers and this delay was exacerbated by cumbersome procurement procedures. These problems were largely responsible for the project being completed four years behind schedule. Some items of equipment were judged to be too sophisticated for the schools and, in the case of some agricultural equipment, not relevant to local conditions. B. Lessons Learned 2.9 Projects assisting technical and secondary education, approved by the Board in June 1996, are too recent to provide operational lessons. However, experience under previous education projects in Thailand, although implemented mainly in the seventies and early eighties, are still relevant to the proposed project. For example, overseas training programs need to be carefully planned especially in relation to the language capabilities of candidates and their ability gain entry to overseas institutions. Careful consideration should also be given to the structure of training programs in relation to the needs for skill acquisition, especially in relation to the mix of available options - formal courses, hands-on experience, seminars, etc. A well-staffed central project implementation unit with appropriate links to participating institutions is essential to ensure successful project implementation. Relevant lessons drawn from Bankwide experience include: (a) the importance of involving end-users in the preparation of equipment lists to ensure their relevance to users' needs; (b) the impact of overseas training projects is measured most appropriately by the number of trainees returning to their posts rather than the number sent abroad; and (c) the need for counterparts to work with expert advisers to ensure that local staff gain from inservice training opportunities. The above lessons have been incorporated in project design. C. Bank's Assistance Strategy 2.10 The Bank's Country Assistance Strategy (CAS) for Thailand (Report No. 1 3458-TH), which was presented to the Board on September 22, 1994, recognizes that Thailand needs selective policy and technical advice and financing. Hence, Bank assistance aims at providing value added in terms of helping to address the most important development issues, many of which are cross-sectoral and involve the provision of public goods. These key development priorities, on which Bank assistance would be focused, are: physical infrastructure provision, human resource development, poverty reduction and improvement in income distribution, and natural resource and environmental management. The CAS envisaged a lending
 17 program of around US$300 million per year during FY96-98 in these priority areas. It was also indicated in the CAS that strong interest on the part of the Government in priority areas such as the social sectors could lead to increased lending. With respect to education, this interest has been declared by the Government through communications with the Bank, in public pronouncements and through high priority being given to education in the Eighth Plan. Consequently, a number of projects were identified which focused on sector priorities in education. 2.11 The proposed project would assist in human resource development. Thailand's economic success has been built on the expansion of manufactured exports, facilitated by substantial foreign direct investment. This export-led growth strategy is now under pressure due to rising real wages, and skill shortages, coupled with economic liberalization in labor-abundant economies such as China, Vietnam and India. A key determinant of Thailand's continued economic success, therefore, will be its ability to upgrade products and processes towards greater technological sophistication. Whether this can be achieved quickly depends critically upon the availability of skilled and educated labor. However, past under-investment in secondary, higher and technical education, together with sectoral policy and institutional weaknesses, have meant that labor quality constraints have become increasingly serious. Education Lending Strategy 2.12 In recent years, post-primary education in Thailand has been unable to meet the demands of a rapidly expanding economy for technical skills and for workers with a sound general education. This has retarded productivity growth while skill shortages have pushed up wages thereby putting pressure on the country's competitiveness. The Government has responded with policies that call for the expansion of technical and scientific education to increase the supply of skills at all levels and also for the expansion of general secondary education to increase the education level of entrants to the workforce and to expand the numbers of potential entrants to higher education. A key concern underlying this expansion is the need to maintain (and preferably improve) the quality of education in the face of rapidly expanding enrollments. 2.13 Prior to restarting lending in 1996 (para. 2.8), the Bank made its last loan for education to Thailand in 1982 in support of developing lower secondary education (para. 2.7). This was followed by a Government policy of not seeking Bank financing in the social sectors. In 1990-91 the Bank prepared an in-depth review of vocational education and a review of key issues in education. These reviews were well-received in Thailand but did not lead to any discernible action to implement the policy recommendations contained therein. However in 1993, recognizing the growing inadequacies in the education system, the Government asked the Bank to look at the possibilities of restarting lending to education. 2.14 The education lending strategy is based on the assumption that if the Bank is to make a meaningful impact on sector development, it must be engaged for the long term. In line
 18 with the CAS, this means that the Bank must be in a position to offer policy advice and, to be realistic, it must be combined with lending operations if the Bank is to have a significant impact on policy improvements. Our lending strategy will follow three stages. The first stage, currently being implemented, covers the design of initial lending operations and constitutes the Bank's re-entry into the sector. The initial round comprises five projects which aim to assist in raising the quality of vocational and technical education, supporting the expansion and quality improvement of secondary education in three strategic subjects - science, mathematics and English and, under the proposed project, strengthening undergraduate science and engineering programs in selected public universities. Such assistance would contribute to the production of better-trained skilled workers, technicians, engineers and scientists, and better-educated outputs from the secondary schools. This would address, directly, one of the critical development problems in Thailand, namely, the severe shortages of technically skilled and educated manpower. Thus, proposed initial Bank assistance is fully consistent with Thailand's development priorities and with the Bank's assistance strategy. 2.15 The second stage calls for the preparation of a policy-oriented sector study to be completed by the Bank in FY97. A number of sound education policies relating to system expansion and quality improvement are currently being implemented and the five initial projects would support these policies. These ongoing policies provide an adequate framework for the effective implementation of the projects and for the sustainability of their outcomes. With respect to university science and engineering education, current policies (paras.1.33-1.37) call for the expansion of enrollments in these fields to alleviate the shortage of scientists and engineers. This would be accompanied by quality improvement measures to upgrade academic staff, strengthen management and planning within faculties, expand the range of teaching programs and upgrade teaching facilities. The design of the proposed project (paras. 3.5-3.9) is clearly consistent with these policies. 2.16 However, in addition to current policies which are pursuing expansion and quality improvement, there are a number of more complex policy issues which, administratively and politically, are proving difficult to resolve. This difficulty is reflected in the fact that the issues are well-known and regularly debated, but reaching a consensus aimed at their resolution has eluded policy-makers to date. The issues include: (a) University autonomy; diminishing bureaucratic control accompanied by greater autonomy of institutional management and academic freedom are desirable in a maturing higher education system such as Thailand's. A measure of autonomy was granted to two new universities and it was planned to extend this to other institutions, but progress has been delayed by the political process. (b) Cost recovery; subsidy levels in public secondary schools and universities are high and benefit higher income groups disproportionately. This needs to be redressed. (c) Role of the private sector; in order to augment long-term resource flows to the education sector, the private sector must play a larger role. This introduces a number of issues relating to incentives, high cost of entry, maintenance of standards, overall level of regulation, etc. (d) Teacher retention; the rapidly expanding private sector is attracting a significant number of teachers, especially those with technical and scientific training. The magnitude of the problem needs to be defined, incentives for retention
 19 introduced and a long-term strategy for teacher development formulated. The proposed sector study, currently under preparation, is analyzing these (and other) issues and will propose appropriate solutions."4 2.17 The sector study would form the basis of a policy dialogue with the Government, which would be monitored during implementation of the ongoing projects. Recommendations aimed at addressing major problems would be defined and set out in an education sector strategy. This strategy would be prepared by the Government and would guide future improvements in education. It would also serve to guide the policy content of future projects. Thus, the third stage of Bank lending would encompass follow-up projects which would include policy content drawn from the Government's sector strategy. It is expected that follow-up projects would continue to support quality improvement in science and technical education. The unmet needs are substantial and continued concentration of effort by the Bank would ensure that a meaningful impact would be made in these areas. Project design would emphasize monitoring and evaluation of policy improvements. 2.18 The Bank's strategy aims for long-term involvement in the education sector. Through continued policy dialogue and carefully targeted lending operations, the Government and the Bank would work towards a cost-effective, well-managed education system which would meet the skill needs of an expanding economy and service the broader needs of a rapidly modernizing society. The initial projects are providing a way for the Bank to re-enter the education sector and to address quickly some obvious needs for quality improvement within the context of the existing policy framework. The Government's policies of expanding enrollments in science and engineering by 15% p.a. aim to overcome the shortages and their success will depend upon two crucial achievements. Second, in a period of expansion special attention needs to be given to maintaining, and preferably improving, quality. ENGINEERING DEGREE PROGRAMS The accreditation practice has a basis similar to the US Accreditation Board for Engineering and Technology , where the various engineering professional societies set periodically the desired distribution of semester hour credits among the basic sciences/mathematics, engineering sciences. In Thailand, before a university opens an engineering undergraduate program, the curriculum and study program proposed by the concerned department are submitted first to the Committee of University Deans examine their implications on other departments and/or faculties of the university and, subsequently, to the University Council for assessment of budgetary implications and approval. The final documents are then presented both to the MUA and the Ministry of the Interior. At the MUA the documents are scrutinized, guided by a number of earlier decrees and regulations to ensure that the proposal meets the credentials required for a university degree. The Ministry of the Interior is vested with the authority to issue professional registration that grants license to sign engineering contracts, undertake construction and operation of projects, plants and equipment above defined capacities. Six engineering professions are listed as requiring registration, these include: civil (including structural, sanitary and environmental), mechanical (including automotive), electrical (including power, computer and telecommunications), industrial (including production), mining and chemical engineering. The Ministry of Interior has delegated this responsibility to the Engineering Institute of Thailand as the professional certification council. Each of the professional societies represented in the Engineering Institute lay down the desired curriculum requirements and professional experience. Consequently, the proposal from a university engineering department initiating an undergraduate degree program is examined by the respective professional society, which may suggest modifications if exemptions are to be granted to holders of that engineering degree program from sitting at the examinations held by the professional society for grant of the professional registration. This grant of exemption is eagerly sought, and nearly 70-80 percent of the engineering curricula in the public universities are in match with the professional societies' requirements, that are modified periodically to keep step with the changing state of the profession.

Capabilities in formulating and presenting research proposals The research culture is not well developed in Thai universities, particularly in Engineering. The quality of both teaching and research suffers as a result. Some key people suggest that because of a braindrain to the private sector and commitments to more remunerative activities, the quantity and quality of research is actually declining. The Government through the new Thailand Research Fund and through incentives to industry is endeavoring to provide funds for research activities. However, motivation, interest and experience need to be developed to fully utilize these new resources. Collaborative research involving Thai and Australian academics are one way of developing an emphasis on research. This can involve small research grants or large collaborative research projects. The first step is to develop skills in defining research projects and in writing for project funding. The activities undertaken will include: (a) Workshops on proposal preparation and presentation, involving technical and English language training: These workshops will be held to develop special skills in identifying research problems and projects and in writing effective applications for research support. Workshops may also cover research management issues. Activities would involve both technical and English language development. (b) Seed funding for development of collaborative research projects: Funds will be provided for exploratory visits and consultations between Thai and Australian researchers on possible research collaboration. Consultants and the research workshops will help identify potential collaborative projects and personnel. 2. Completion of minor research projects for returned scholars or new staff: These small studies will serve to encourage staff to develop research activities and enhance their interest and skills in research. They will be aimed at building on the enthusiasm of newly returned graduates from postgraduate training or other new staff. These studies will have Australian involvement through contacts with Consultants and Experts.

(c) Collaborative research projects undertaken and completed: Projects will be funded and completed within the Guidelines and under the agreed administrative procedure. Funds will be provided for seed activities, small projects and collaborative research projects. V. English Language Training for Science and Engineering 1. Improved ESP teaching for Science and Engineering in Thai universities Both staff and students in Science and Engineering require English language skills to enable them to take opportunities for overseas contacts or scholarships and to keep up with international developments in Science and Engineering. For staff, the opportunities may be in Thailand or overseas. They may involve on-the-job staff development, upgrading of academic qualifications or collaborative research. Many staff will seek scholarship training overseas, and find limited English a major stumbling block in taking up such opportunities. the project can provide support for early English language leaming and for predeparture English for staff who will use their scholarships to go to Australia. ELT can also be integrated into other Science and Engineering staff development components. For students, there are already English language subjects in all undergraduate Science and Engineering programs. Students need better English language skills to gain access to the best access to the best employment opportunities or pursue further study. With better focused ESP activities, the time spent on English language learning can be more productive. The activities undertaken will include: (a) Advisory services to Thai universities on course and program development for courses in ESP for Science and Engineering staff and students.
 48 ANNEX 4 (Page 11 of 13) The Australian Adviser will provide professional ESP training needs analysis, advice on integrated ESP teaching activities, facilitation and coordination of all ELT activities in the project. A Thai counterpart will work with the Adviser for a period and then continue to provide advice and coordination in ELT activities. (b) Needs Analysis of ELT for working with Australian Science and Engineering Experts: In the first year a series of workshops will be run for Science and Engineering staff to identify skill gaps and increase their language skills and awareness for working with Australian advisers and experts. Other workshops will be held on specific skill areas in later years. (c) ESP workshops for EFL staff: ESP experts will come from Australia to run workshops for ELT staff on specific topics, such as principles of ESP teaching, ESP materials development, development of ESP self-access centers, delivering IELTS Preparation courses and preparation for academic study in Australia. (d) Study visits to Australia for ELT staff: Study visits will be for specific purposes such as observation of working self-access centers, observation of methods for use of authentic texts and familiarization with requirements for academic study in Australia. 2. Development of Computer Assisted Language Learning module for Science and Engineering. Work will be undertaken to develop a Computer Assisted Language Learning (CALL) module for Science and Engineering undergraduates. It is intended that this will be available in self-access areas and will encourage student interest in and activities in English language learning. The development work will be contracted to a Thai university, with assistance and monitoring by an Australian CALL expert. The Project will provide training for ELT staff in using the CALL module. Trials will be held, leading to modifications and revision. The module will be distributed to all Thai universities. Copyright will remain with the Australian government unless otherwise agreed. The activities undertaken will include: (a) Tender and assignment of the project: The contractor will work with Thai Staff to draft specifications. The target user groups are second year
 49 ANNEX 4 (Page 12 of 13) Science and Engineering students. A tender will be called among Thai university staff to develop this module. (b) Design and development of module: A CALL expert from Australia will assist in specifications and in ensuring that the module is of high quality and is able to be used throughout Thailand. (c) Pilot trailing of module in country: trails will be held using the module to refine and revise the module. (d) Staff training to use modules: The project will provide training to ELT staff in the use of the module at both the pilot and implementation stages. 3. Increased IELTS scores of scholarship candidates Difficulties in meeting English language test scores required by overseas universities limit staff utilization of overseas scholarships. For staff interested in going to Australia on their MUA scholarship, the Project will fund a number of scholarships for pre- departure English language training rough ELCA to bring them up to acceptable levels of English language. These courses should also include study skills and other preparatory activities. The activities undertaken will include: (a) Scholarships for ELCA IELTS Preparation courses (on-site): Scholarships, who wish to go to Australia, for English language skills development focused on EAP and IELTS. Where there is a sufficient group of students, and it is an effective solution, courses will be run by ELCA staff at a provincial center. Where a group of participants is put together from different institutions, including Bangkok ones, courses will be run by ELCA staff at ELCA in Bangkok. Inputs One 12 month Adviser and one (Thai national) ELT Coordinator. Expert visits and the provision of workshops in country will be provided. The development

(b) Reporting and monitoring: The Contractor will provide quarterly and other reports as required. Progress reports will be considered at six monthly Project Coordinating Committee meetings. doc.abstracts: The overall objective of the Universities Science and Engineering Education Project is to improve the quality of undergraduate science and engineering programs. Specifically, the project aims to: a) strengthen faculty teaching capabilities; b) upgrade the existing science and engineering program content and broaden the range of programs relevant to Thailand's technological advancement; c) modernize laboratories and strengthen their management; and d) improve resource utilization in engineering and science faculties and establish a system for large-scale equipment procurement. The project will support quality improvement in public universities through financing an institutional development program which will include: a) short term overseas training for selected academic and technical support staff in the educational use and maintenance of the project-financed equipment; and b) technical assistance and academic support services which will provide consultant services to evaluate existing programs and recommend new ones, improve the program resource management, develop effective procedures for large scale equipment procurement and strengthen project management. This component will also include small-scale research projects financing for academic and technical staff selected for overseas training. Teaching equipment will be financed for undergraduate programs together with installation costs. Incremental expenditure on equipment related operation and maintenance, consumable material, and project management support will also be included in the project.
